dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A violent struggle is in progress: CLOSE on a man's thick fleshy hand, as it grips the two slender wrists of a youn girl, who's trying desperately to free herself, grunting with effort. A WIDER ANGLE shows us that there are three people in the carriage, the third, a man in uniform on his knees in a c hanging on to the girl's feet and lower legs as she jerks and flails like a landed fish. The GIRL is SABINA SPIELRE a dark, slight young woman of 19, olive-skinned and beaut with waist-length dark hair. The MAN gripping her wrists her father NIKOLAI SPIELREIN, a large, coarse-looking, re faced Russian in his midforties, with a thick moustache. Abruptly, SABINA stops struggling; but the relief, palpab on the faces of the two men, is short-lived: for SABINA b to wail, terrible, broken-hearted sobs to freeze the bloo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright summer day pours sunlight on the COACHMAN as he lashes the horses on, up a hill leading away from the lar expanse of the lake. A CAPTION: ZURICH, SWITZERLAND: 17TH AUGUST, 1904.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Burgh√©lzli hospital is a massive, plain building on t crest of a hill. The COACHMAN jumps down to open the door and help the ORDERLY and NIKOLAI SPIELREIN as they emerge seen from ABOVE, carrying the writhing body of SABINA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the MEN labour in with the struggling SABINA, she sudd goes limp and begins shrieking with laughter. Two or three NURSES close in on her as the ORDERLY drops legs; while other NURSES arrive down various corridors, attracted by the noise. SABINA stops laughing and sticks her tongue out as far as it will go at the approaching NU causing SPIELREIN to smack her round the head; at which, hysterical laughter begins again.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLOSE on SABINA: screaming with laughter, until suddenly, her eyes flick upwards and she stops again in the middle a peal of laughter: she's seen something. Descending the main staircase is DR. CARL GUSTAV JUNG, a tall, broad-shouldered, godlike young man of 29, haloed i backlit glow and smiling faintly as he purposefully approaches. SABINA is still now, staring up at the apparition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA sits, bolt upright on a straight-backed chair, in dead centre of a bare white room. She's wearing a simple dress and her hair has been braided into one long plait. There's another chair placed about five or six feet behin her, slightly to one side. JUNG breezes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Good morning, I'm Dr. Jung, I admitted you last night. He stretches out a hand, but she won't take it. This does seem to discourage him in the least.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: They wouldn't let me keep the light on.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You like to sleep with the light on?

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: Her mouth stays open, she seems to be making an enormous, unsuccessful effort to speak.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I think we can allow that. SABINA closes her mouth, relief in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'm not mad, you know.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 3.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Let me explain what I have in mind: I propose that we meet here, most days, to talk for an hour or two.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Talk?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes. Just talk. See if we can identify what's troubling you. So as to distract you as little as possible, I shall sit there, behind you; and I'm going to ask you to try not to turn round and look at me under any circumstances. He moves behind her and sits in the second chair. Her fac twitches, her expression is apprehensive. JUNG opens a sm notebook on his knee, in which he will make regular notes

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now. Have you any idea what may have brought on these attacks you suffer from? SABINA has to struggle for some time before she can answe

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Humiliation. Silence. JUNG waits. SABINA'S head jerks back in a series involuntary tics.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any kind of... humiliation, I can't bear to see it. Makes me feel nauseated. I start pouring with sweat, cold sweat.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No one likes to see that kind of thing. But these must have been isolated incidents? Silence. SABINA is in obvious distress.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were they not?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 4.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: No, often, they were often, happened often.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: At home?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: My... father lost his temper all the time, he was always angry: with my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: With your brothers?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Not with you?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Sometimes... ah, sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What would he do?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Shout and... shout. And hit them. She's writhing in her chair now, her leg twitching, her f out of control.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: But you do love your father?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, but I couldn't... I couldn't... he was so sad sometimes and I wasn't able to... pride... it was the most painful kind of love... I couldn't even... couldn't kiss him... She breaks off. JUNG waits a while.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: When you stopped talking just now: did a thought come into your head?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 5.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I don't... ah...

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Or an image perhaps? Was it an image?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What was the image?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: A hand. She writhes in her chair; finally she comes to rest and speaks, only just audibly.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My father's hand.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why do you think you saw that?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: After he... whenever he hit us... afterwards... we had to kiss his hand... She twists and turns; JUNG writes in his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment assigned to the hospital's assistant direct is a set of plain rooms on the second floor of the hospit comfortably furnished by JUNG's wife, EMMA, a fair, attra 22-year-old, now five months pregnant. JUNG has finished his breakfast and sips his coffee as EM moves around, clearing the table.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What's odd is, that case I was writing up last week: I happened to pick the codename Sabina S. And here she is: Sabina Spielrein.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 6.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Quite a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: As you know, I don't believe there is such a thing. EMMA puts his empty cup on the tray.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Spielrein's not a very Russian name.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No, Jewish. Father's a very successful import-export man. And she's exceptionally well educated, speaks fluent German. Aspires to be a doctor herself, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Perhaps she's the one.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What one?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: The one you've been looking for. For your experimental treatment. The talking cure.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: (smiles) You're so astute. I've already begun it with her. EMMA lays a hand on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: He's kicking, can you feel? JUNG rests a hand on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. There he is. He starts to put on his jacket and straightens his tie, preparing to leave.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 7.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What I don't understand is why Freud, having proposed this radical therapeutic idea, this talking cure, this psychanalysis, then lets years go by without giving even the barest outline of his clinical procedures? What's he playing at?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Presumably he uses the method on his patients?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I've no idea.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: So might you be the first doctor to try this out?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Why don't you write and ask him?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I don't know him. As it happens, Miss Spielrein's mother wanted to take her to see Freud.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Another coincidence. Her tone is teasing; JUNG shakes his head, pecks her affectionately on the cheek and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and SABINA stroll through the towering pines which c the slopes of a hill near the Burghd√©lzli. They're wearin overcoats, SABINA's worn draped across her shoulders. SAB seems more relaxed; JUNG carries a stout walking-stick.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: My father thinks my mother doesn't love him... and he's right, she doesn't.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 8.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: My angel told me.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What angel?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: An inner voice. He used to tell me I was an exceptional person. For some reason he always spoke in German.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Angels always speak German: it's traditional. SABINA smiles, perhaps for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: He gave me the power to know what people are going to say before they open their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Useful ability for a doctor. You hope to be a doctor someday, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'll never be a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why not? SABINA looks up at him gratefully: they walk on for a whi in silence.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to go away for a while. I'm sorry. We've just gotten started. SABINA looks up at him, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Military service. We all have to do it. Just for a couple of weeks.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SABINA starts trembling; her expression darkens.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: It's all a waste of time. I can't tell you whatever it is you want to know, you're just making me angry... and if I did tell you, you'd be sorry you ever... anyway, there's nothing wrong with me! I don't even want to get better! She instinctively pulls away from him, her coat catches o branch and is swept off onto the dusty ground. JUNG picks up, holds it out and starts to beat the dust out of it wi his stick. Suddenly, SABINA hurls herself at him and snat the coat out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I was only...

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Will you stop that!

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. SABINA looks at him for a moment, her expression fearful; then she looks away and speaks abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Can we go back now?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes, if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I need to get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG folds his army uniform and closes his suitcase. EMMA hovers sympathetically in the background.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It's a complete waste of my time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 10.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Writing prescriptions for athlete's foot and examining cocks from morning to night.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Is that what you do?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It's not good for me and it's not good for my patients. INT. SABINA'S ROOM ‚Äî- DAY SABINA's lunch is untouched and she's busying herself wit holding her napkin over a candle-flame, burning tiny hole in it. An takes the tray. The NURSE older NURSE comes in, sees what SABINA is doing, napkin gently from her and turns to look at her

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You haven't eaten your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Not hungry. leans in to collect the tray, then checks herself.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Where's the knife?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Nobody eats on Mars.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Is that so? Now where have you put the knife?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I might need it.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I shall have to tell Professor Bleuler.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Do what you like.  10 11 12 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROFESSOR EUGEN BLEULER, the director of the Burgh√©lzli, diminutive, but distinguished-looking, white-bearded gentleman, follows the NURSE to the door of SABINA's room INT. SABINA'S ROOM ‚Äî- DAY 11 The room is empty. However, a piece of paper is pinned to the wall by a knife. The NURSE crosses to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: BLEULER
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: "If I'm not back tomorrow, it doesn't necessarily mean I'm dead." BLEULER sighs, shaking his head dispiritedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining. BLEULER and the NURSE come upon a small kno of struggling ORDERLIES, at the centre of which is SABINA her face and arms smeared with wet mud. She's grappling fruitlessly with the largest ORDERLY, but stops as soon a BLEULER appears.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Ah. The Herr Direktor. BLEULER's manner is entirely calm.

dialogues.speaker: BLEULER
dialogues.text: Miss Spielrein, I feel you may have a little too much time on your hands. I'm a great believer in getting our patients involved in some productive work. What are your particular interests?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Suicide. Interplanetary travel. BLEULER turns, not rising to this.

dialogues.speaker: BLEULER
dialogues.text: Shall we go in? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 14 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 12.

dialogues.speaker: BLEULER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When Dr. Jung returns, I shall ask him to discuss all this with you in more detail.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: No. Keep him away from me. I never want to see him again. By now, she's allowing the ORDERLIES to begin leading her back towards the hospital, laughing loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a strange-looking contraption in the middle of th room: a dark wooden bath with metal attachments, two-thir full of water. Next to it, SABINA is grappling with three NURSES, kicking and shouting. Eventually they manage to get her undressed and into the bath, whereupon something rather like a coffin-lid, leavi only SABINA's head free, is banged across the top of the bath and secured. SABINA begins to wail, as one of the NU starts to wash the mud off her face. INT. SABINA'S ROOM ‚Äî- DAY 14 SABINA lies on her bed, the picture of apathy. JUNG steps into the room, radiating energy.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Hello. I'm back. (pause) How have you been? SABINA doesn't answer: she turns her face to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've been talking to the Herr Direktor about finding some work for you. I told him you'd always been interested in medicine. He suggested you might like to assist me occasionally in my research. SABINA's face lights up.  14 15 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 13.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're quite short-staffed, so it would certainly be a help to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA JUNG, noticeably more pregnant, sits in a straightba chair, hooked up to an electro-galvanometer; JUNG, holdin clipboard, sits at an angle so that he can monitor the galvanometer; and SABINA, in a white lab coat, sits off t one side, with a stopwatch and a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Woods.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Box.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Bed.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Money.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Bank.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Child. EMMA hesitates. JUNG leans forward, noting that the hand the dial of the galvanometer has jumped.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Family. Pause. SABINA activates her stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Unit.  15 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Sex.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Er, male.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Wall.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Flower.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Young. Another pause; and a reaction on the galvanometer.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Baby.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Ask.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Answer.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Cap.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Wear.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Give way.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Ruefulness. SABINA records about ten seconds on the stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Child.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Fame.
15  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 15.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Divorce. The galvanometer reacts wildly; SABINA watches the tickin hand on the stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No. JUNG relaxes with a warm smile and disconnects EMMA from machine.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: How did I do?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Beautifully. Slightly surprised still, EMMA heaves herself to her feet She crosses to the door, glancing at SABINA en route.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Erm, yes, goodbye. She leaves the room. JUNG turns to SABINA.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Any preliminary observations?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Obviously what's uppermost in her mind is her pregnancy.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 16.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: She's a little... what's the word?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why don't we try a useful word invented by our Herr Direktor: ambivalent.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes... about the baby.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'd say she was worried her husband might be losing interest in her.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Long reaction times to the words ‚Äòfamily' and ‚Äòdivorce‚Äô.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: When you said 'cap', she said 'wear'. Might that be a reference to contraception? JUNG smiles, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You've quite a flair for this.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Of course.  15 16 17 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 17.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Is she your wife? At first taken aback, JUNG recovers quickly and nods, smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG steps into the room where EMMA is nursing her new-bo baby. She looks up at him, her expression defensive.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I promised you a son on Christmas Day. And here she is, a day late and the wrong sex.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd. He leans forward, caressing the baby's forehead with his great hand.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A for Agathe.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Next time I'll give you a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and SABINA in their customary positions: judging by grimace JUNG makes as he uncrosses his legs, they've been there for some time. Eventually, SABINA breaks the silenc

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Can we stop now?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'd like to go on a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: But it's been... I mean, how long has it been?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 18.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: We've been talking for about two and a half hours.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Then why can't we...?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It's my belief that there's one more step to be taken; and as this is our first session of the New Year, I have a sense that progress is possible.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I don't know what to tell you. JUNG waits for a moment before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Can you explain why your nights have been so bad?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: There's something in the room... something like a cat, only it... can speak, it gets into bed with me. Long silence. JUNG waits.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last, last night, it suddenly whispered something in my ear, I couldn't hear what... but then... I felt it behind me... it put its hand on my waist and then... She's twisting furiously in the chair, in an agony of discomfort.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 19.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-.-I felt something against my back, something slimy like some kind of a... mollusc... moving against my back, but when I turned round there was nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You felt it against your back?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Were you naked?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Were you masturbating?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes. Another long silence. JUNG seems about to break it, when SABINA speaks again.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I loathe New Years... JUNG sits up, suddenly alert.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: For example, last New Year's Day... he flew into a terrible rage, nobody could understand why, and he took my brother Isaac... and... and... A tremendous barrage of tics overwhelms her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--beat him in front of everyone... and... I... I...  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She can't go on.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: We've talked a lot about these outbursts of your father's. There were times, weren't there, when he did beat you?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, often, he often...

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Tell me about those. SABINA's eyes dart from place to place; she looks trapped and panicky.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Can we stop now?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'd like to go on just a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: So... ah... She's struggling to control herself.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was the question?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Tell me about the first time you can remember being beaten by your father. SABINA looks as if she's contemplating running out of the room. Finally, she manages to speak.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I suppose I was about four... I broke a plate... or... yes... and he told me to go in the little room and... take my clothes off... then he came in and... spanked me... I was so frightened, I wet myself, so he... hit me again and...  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 21.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: And after that first time, he beat you a lot?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes... yes... and when he was away, my mother beat me... but that wasn't at all... it wasn't the same as... Tears are starting to roll down her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: That first time, how did you feel about what was happening? Long silence; after which, SABINA's reply is scarcely aud

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I liked it.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Would you repeat that, please? I couldn't quite hear.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I liked it. It excited me.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: And did you continue to like it? SABINA gives a long groan.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes... yes... before long he only had to say to me to... go to the little room and I would... start to get wet...

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Did you sometimes provoke him deliberately?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: No, I... it happened often enough... She breaks off: JUNG waits.  17 18 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 22.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whenever he beat one of my brothers - or even just threatened... that was enough... I'd have to go and lie down and touch myself... later, at school, anything would set it off... any kind of humiliation... I looked for any humiliation... even here... when you hit my coat with your stick, I had to come back right away... I was so excited... A torrent of sobbing slowly plays itself out: then she's still at last and her voice is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's no hope for me, I'm vile and filthy and corrupt, I must never be let out of here... Her head sinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and EMMA descend from a taxi outside No.19, Berggass a quiet street in Vienna 9. As JUNG pays the taxi and tur towards the house, the front door opens to reveal a sligh bearded man of medium height, conservatively dressed in f coat and stiff collar: this is PROFESSOR SIGMUND FREUD at 50.

dialogues.speaker: A CAPTION
dialogues.text: FREUD steps forward to shake hands warmly with JUNG.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Professor Freud.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: So good to meet you at long last. He shakes hands with EMMA, with a courtly little bow.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're most welcome. He turns to lead them into the house.  19 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are eleven people at lunch in the slightly cramped conditions of the FREUD family dining-room: in addition t FREUD, JUNG and EMMA are FREUD's wife, MARTHA, his sister law, MINNA BERNAYS, and his six children, ranging in age from MATHILDE, 19, to ANNA, 11. FREUD sits next to JUNG a one end of the table, while EMMA sits at the far end with the two adult women. A MAID squeezes around the outside o the table, offering food.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Perhaps the terms themselves should be reviewed: if, for instance, we could come up with some milder term than 'libido', we might not encounter such emotional resistance, it would make the teaching side of things much easier... He breaks off, obliged to move his chair, so that the MAI can pass and offer him food. He helps himself unselfconsciously to an enormous quantity.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Is euphemism a good idea? Once they work out what we actually mean, they'1l be just as appalled as ever. He can't help frowning as he takes note of the vast quant of food on JUNG's plate.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I take your point, but I still think it's worth trying to sweeten the pill when it comes to questions of sexuality...

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: And by the way, please don't feel you have to restrain yourself here. My family are all veterans of the most unsuitable topics of mealtime conversation. JUNG glances around for a second, slightly nonplussed, si it's never occurred to him to take the mixed company into consideration. Then he plunges on.  19 20 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 24.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I have a number of clinical examples which I believe support my position with regard to sexuality...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on FREUD's cigar, as he lights and puffs at it, releasing thick smoke into the homely atmosphere of his cluttered study, furnished in late-Victorian style, with Turkey rugs, a scattering of family photographs, a mass o classical etchings and drawings on the walls and innumera decorative objects, mostly small archaeological pieces, covering every surface. Floor to ceiling bookshelves cove two walls.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: And how is your little Russian patient?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: As I told you, after the initial abreaction, there was the most dramatic improvement. We've enrolled her in the medical school at the University, where she's doing extremely well. She's a walking advertisement for the effectiveness of psychanalysis.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Psychoanalysis.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: It's more logical and it sounds better.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Are you still treating her?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 25.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes; and we continue to unearth new material: for example, the extraordinary procedure she devised as a small child, where she would sit on one heel, attempt to defecate and, at the same time, try to prevent herself from defecating. She said this gave rise to the most blissful feelings.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: A nice story. Those of my patients who remain fixated at the anal stage of their erotic development often come up with the most amusing details. And of course all of them are finicky, compulsively tidy, stubborn and extremely stingy with money. No doubt your Russian conforms to this pattern.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Well, no: she doesn't. FREUD frowns: he puffs at his cigar, evidently somewhat p out.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The masochistic aspects of her condition are much more deeply rooted than any anal fixations we may have uncovered.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: But the two are intimately connected!

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I can only tell you she's rather disorganised, emotionally generous and exceptionally idealistic.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps it's a Russian thing. He looks across at JUNG, eyes narrowed.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is she a virgin?  20 21 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 26.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes, certainly. Almost certainly. No, certainly. His slight confusion is not lost on FREUD, who sucks on h cigar, his good mood quite restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG, fork in hand, is tucking into an enormous slab of Sachertorte, accompanied by a large cup of coffee piled h with whipped cream. FREUD, a chaste cup of black coffee in front of him, watc him benevolently. Behind, the coffee house is thronged wi men, deep in animated conversation, reading newspapers fr the racks or playing chess.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I don't think you have any notion of the true strengths and depths of the opposition to our work. There's the whole medical establishment, of course, baying to send Freud to the auto-da-f√©; but that's as nothing compared to what happens when our ideas begin to trickle through in whatever garbled form they're relayed to the public: the denials, the frenzy, the incoherent rage... you wouldn't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: But might that not be caused by your insistence on the exclusively sexual interpretation of the clinical material?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: All I'm doing is pointing out what experience indicates to me must be the truth... And I can assure you that in a hundred years' time our work will still be rejected. Columbus, you know, had no idea what county he'd discovered; like him, I'm in the dark: all I know is that I've set foot on the shore and the country exists.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 27.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I think of you more as Galileo: and your opponents as those who condemned him, while refusing even to put their eye to his telescope.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: In any event, I've simply opened a door: it's for the young men, like yourself, to walk through it.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm sure you have many more doors to open for us.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: At your age, I had made no mark at all: whereas you, for example, have invented the indispensable word ‚Äòcomplex'.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I hope to be remembered for more than just a single word.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: And I've no doubt you will be. He stubs out his cigar and drains his coffee, looking int across at JUNG.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course, there's the added difficulty, more ammunition for our enemies, that all of us here in Vienna, in our psychoanalytical circle, are Jews.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I don't see what difference that makes. FREUD looks at him: he's staring innocently across, his moustache thick with white cream.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: That, if I may say so, is an exquisitely Protestant remark.  22 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's deep into the night, but FREUD and JUNG's conversati is still in full flow.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I dreamed about a horse, being hoisted by cables to a considerable height. Suddenly, a cable breaks and the horse is dashed to the ground. But it's not hurt, it leaps up and gallops away, impeded only by a heavy log, which it's obliged to drag along the ground. Then a rider on a small horse appears in front of it, so that it's forced to slow down; and a carriage appears in front of the small horse, so that our horse is compelled to slow down even more. FREUD considers for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I imagine the horse is yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Your ambition has been frustrated in some way; hence the fall.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: The rider slowing me down...

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I think this may refer to my wife's first pregnancy. I had to give up an opportunity to go to America because of it.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Ah, America. You're right, I'm sure that's a most important territory for us.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: The carriage in front perhaps refers to an apprehension that our two daughters and other children perhaps still to come, will impede my progress even more.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: As a father of six, I can vouch for that; not to mention the inevitable financial difficulties.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No. Fortunately my wife is extremely rich. FREUD takes a moment to recover from this. He forces

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Ah. Yes, that is fortunate. himself to return to the matter in hand.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This log.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I think perhaps you should entertain the possibility that it represents the penis.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes; in which case what may be at issue is that a certain sexual constraint has been brought about by a fear of an endless succession of pregnancies. As FREUD answers, JUNG begins the elaborate process lighting his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Hm. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of 29. 22  22 23 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 30.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm bound to say if one of my patients had brought me this dream, I might have said that the number of restraining elements surrounding this unfortunate horse could perhaps point to the determined suppression of some unruly sexual desire.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes. He sucks his pipe for a while.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is that as well. FREUD permits himself a satisfied smile; the clock on his desk shows it's coming up to 2 a.m. JUNG nods

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I wonder if you're aware of the fact that our conversation has so far lasted thirteen hours?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I had no idea...

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: My dear young colleague, please don't apologise. It was our first meeting, we had a great deal to say to one another; and unless I'm much mistaken, we always will. solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and SABINA make their way down the hill towards the lake, deep in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I've never met anyone like him. Nothing passes him by. He understands everything. I suppose he's what's meant by a great man. I shall have to be extremely careful.  23 24 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 31.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Why?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: He's so persuasive, he's so convincing, he makes you feel you should abandon your own ideas and simply follow in his wake. His followers in Vienna are all deeply unimpressive: a crowd of Bohemians and degenerates just picking up the crumbs from his table.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Perhaps he's reached the stage where obedience is more important to him than originality.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Mm. I tried to tackle him about his obsession with sexuality, his insistence on interpreting every symptom in sexual terms, but he's completely inflexible.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: In my case, of course, he'd have been right.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes, as you would expect him to be in many cases. Possibly even the majority of cases. He shakes his head, troubled, as they approach the ferry station.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But there must be more than one hinge into the universe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG stands, leaning over the handrail, looking out acros the lake. He's momentarily taken aback by a question from SABINA.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Do you like Wagner?  24 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 32.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They both 24

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: The music and the man, yes.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'm very interested in the myth of Siegfried: the idea that something pure and heroic can come, can perhaps only come, from a sin, even a sin as dark as incest.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: This is very strange.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I've told you before I don't believe in coincidence, I believe nothing happens by accident, all these things have a significance: the fact is, I'm in the middle of writing something myself about the Siegfried myth. look at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Are you really?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Which is your favourite of the operas?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Das Rheingold.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes. That's right. Me too. Her eyes are shining with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Perhaps we might go to the opera sometimes. My wife has never been interested.  24 25 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 33.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'd love to. She looks up at him, hesitant: then decides to take the plunge.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Do you think there's any possibility I could ever be a psychiatrist? JUNG contemplates her eager expression.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I know you could. I hear nothing but good reports on your work at the University. You're exactly the kind of person we need.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Insane, you mean. JUNG frowns; then he realises she's joking and his expres lightens.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes; we sane doctors have serious limitations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD at his desk, pen in hand, poised above a sheet of w notepaper with PROF. DR. FREUD modestly printed in the to left corner. He writes the date, 17.02.08 in large, spide handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear friend, I feel I can at last permit myself this informal mode of address as I ask you to grant me a very particular favour...  26 27 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall, thin, bearded man with piercing blue eyes, wearin fraying but elegant suit, pauses to look up at the cheerl fagade of the hospital. This is OTTO GROSS. He's thirty.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-Dr. Otto Gross, a most brilliant but erratic character, is urgently in need of your medical help. I consider him, apart from yourself, the only man capable of making a major contribution to our field. GROSS reaches into his waistcoat pocket and brings out a pinch of white powder, which he carelessly inhales.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, don't let him out before October, when I shall be able to take him over from you. And remember his father's warning, made when Otto was only a very small child: watch out for him, he bites! GROSS blinks, shakes his head to clear it and reluctantly advances through the hospital entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROSS is smoking, his feet stretched out in front of him, slumped comfortably in his chair; JUNG on the other hand, behind his desk, looks somewhat constrained and anxious.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You still feel threatened by your father?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Anyone with any sense feels threatened by my father. He's extremely threatening. To you, of course, he's an eminent criminologist, the man who virtually invented a whole new science: footprints, fingerprints, bloodstains, semen samples; but to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 35.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: me he's a man with a very simple aim: to put every single person he disapproves of in jail. You don't have to be a criminal; in fact, he wrote a pamphlet explaining that anarchists, tramps, homosexuals, gypsies and perverts - people like me - were far more dangerous than honest criminals and should be deported to South-West Africa. So, in my view, if you didn't feel threatened by my father, you'd need your head examined.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: His wish to have you hospitalised: you don't think that arises from a concern for your welfare?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Listen: what does any normal old patriach want in the twilight of his life? Grandchildren, grandsons, am I right? And yet, last summer, when I presented him with not one, but two little Grosses, one by my wife, one by one of most respectable mistresses, and we called them both Peter, so he wouldn't get confused, was he grateful? And now there's another on the way, admittedly by some woman I hardly know, he's apoplectic; and all he can think is to get me banged away in some institution. You got any children?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Two girls.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Same mother?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Ah.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pause. JUNG fiddles with his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: So you're not a believer in monogamy?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: For a neurotic like myself, I can't possibly imagine a more stressful concept.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: And you don't find it necessary or desirable to exercise some restraint, as a contribution, say, to the smooth functioning of civilisation?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: What, and make myself ill?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I should have thought that some form of sexual repression would have to be practised in any rational society.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: No wonder the hospitals are bulging at the seams. He reaches into a waistcoat pocket, fetches something out and pops it in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you going to help me cut down on this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Good, because it's doing my head in. He leans forward, his manner suddenly conspiratorial.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me, do you find the best way to enhance your popularity with your patients is to tell them whatever it is they most want to hear?  27 28 29

dialogues.speaker: AND
dialogues.text: 30 PINK Revision - 6/6/10 37-38.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Does it matter whether we're popular with them or not?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know: suppose you want to fuck them? JUNG looks across at GROSS, not sure if he's joking. What says next is deadly serious.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I've learned in my short life, it's this: never repress anything!

dialogues.speaker: INT. THERAPY HALL. BURGHOLZLI- EVENING
dialogues.text: A small hall in the hospital reserved for music and performance therapy. About thirty restless patients sit o steel-frame chairs, listening to an opera playing on an elegant wax-cylinder phonograph with a large brass trumpe like speaker. An ornately dramatic theatrical poster on the wall behind the table identifies the opera as Wagner's DIE WALKURE. An enormous crash of MUSIC: it's the moment close to the of Act I when Siegmund approaches the sword, Notung, plun up to the hilt in a tree-trunk. SABINA and JUNG, sitting on either side of the table supporting the gramophone, scan the audience for reaction and scribble notes on matching notepads. As the love-duet between Sieglinde and Siegmund reaches a ecstatic climax, SABINA, rapt by the music despite her de to remain clinical and objective, casts an ardent glance towards JUNG, only to find that he is watching her with t same passionate intensity. Sabina flushes and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: AND
dialogues.text: 30  31 PINK Revision - 6/6/10 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OTTO GROSS looks across the desk at JUNG, his eyes sparkl with mischief and provocation.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: So you've never slept with any of your patients?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Of course not: you have to steer through the temptations of transference and countertransference, that's an essential stage of the process.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: When transference occurs, when the patient becomes fixated on me, I explain to her that this is merely a (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31  31 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 40.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: symbol of her wretched monogamous habits: I show her that it's fine to want to sleep with me, but only if, at the same time, she acknowledges to herself that she wants to sleep with a great many other people.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Suppose she doesn't?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Then it's my job to convince her that's part of the illness. JUNG shakes his head, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is what people are like. If we don't tell them the truth, who will?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You think Freud's right? You think all neurosis is of exclusively sexual origin?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: I think Freud's obsession with sex probably has a great deal to do with the fact that he never gets any.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You could be right.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: It seems to me a measure of the true perversity of the human race that one of its very few reliably pleasurable activities should be the subject of so much hysteria and repression.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: But not to repress yourself is to unleash all kinds of dangerous and destructive forces.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 41.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Our job is to make our patients capable of freedom.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I've heard it said you helped one of your patients to kill herself.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: She was resolutely suicidal. I just explained how she could do it without botching it. Then I asked her if she didn't prefer the idea of becoming my lover. She opted for both.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: That can't be what we want for our patients.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Freedom is freedom. He sits up, suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Life being what it is, the more sensitive you are, the sicker you'll become. So I say, whenever you see an oasis, you must always remember to drink. Quite suddenly, a stream of dark blood begins to flow fro one nostril. He dabs at himself, then looks down at the blood on his fingertips. JUNG hands him a white handkerch which he uses to clean up, as the blood continues to flow

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gave up the opium; you can't expect me to give up the cocaine as well.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I think you must: I don't see how you can go on. GROSS's expression suddenly turns defiant.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: I'll use the other fucking nostril!  32

dialogues.speaker: 32B
dialogues.text: PINK Revision - 6/6/10 42.%

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and SABINA walk along the border of Lake Ziirich, bo deep in thought. At a certain point, she takes his arm an steers him towards a small promontory. EXT. PROMONTORY NEAR SCHONLEINSTRASSE ‚Äî DAY 32B* A small cobble-stoned space with a bench and a few plane trees, the lake spreading out before it. SABINA steers JU towards the bench.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Can we talk for a moment? *

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Of course. * They sit down. *

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about Wagner's * opera. In it, he says that perfection * can only be arrived at through what is conventionally thought of as sin, is that right? Which must surely have to do with the energy created by the friction of opposites: not just that you're the doctor and I'm the patient, but that you're Swiss and I'm Russian; I'm Jewish and you're Aryan; and all kinds of other darker differences.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Darker? *

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: If I'm right, only the clash of * destructive forces can create something new. She reaches out to take his hand. *

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When my father brought me to you, I * was very ill; and my illness was sexual. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 PINK Revision - 6/6/10 42A.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's clear that the subject I'm studying is entirely grounded in sexuality. So naturally I'm becoming more and more acutely aware of the fact that I have no sexual experience.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Law students are not normally expected to rob banks. They smile at each other; then, impulsively, SABINA reach up, puts her hand round the back of JUNG's neck and kisse him on the lips. The kiss lasts some while; eventually, h breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's generally thought to be the man who should take the initiative.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Don't you think there's something male in every woman? And something female in every man? Or should be? JUNG considers this for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Maybe. I expect you're right. Yes. You must be. SABINA points across at a tall gray stone apartment build No. 7, Schd√©nleinstrasse.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: If you ever want to take the initiative, I live in that building, there, where the bay window is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful summer's day and JUNG is talking to OTTO GROSS in a kind of pergola in the hospital gardens. GROSS sits back, his hands linked behind his handsome head; it' as if he's the doctor and JUNG is the patient.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: I can't understand what you're waiting for. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision - 6/6/10 42B.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just take her to some secluded spot and thrash her to within an inch of her life: that's clearly what she wants. How can you deny her such a simple pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Pleasure is never simple, as you very well know.  33 34 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 43.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: It is, of course it is, until we decide to complicate it. The tragedy of childhood is the moment we understand we can never have everything we want; the tragedy of adulthood is the moment we decide not to take everything we can have: what my father calls maturity, what I call surrender.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Surrender, for me, would be to give in to these urges.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Then surrender: doesn't matter what you call it, as long as you don't let the experience escape. That's my prescription.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be treating you.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Yes, and it's been most effective.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'd say the analysis was not too far from completion.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Mine, yes. Not so sure about yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and SABINA have reached a moment of informality at t end of her consultation.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I've been spending so much time with him, I'm afraid I'm neglecting some of my other patients. He's immensely seductive, quite sure he's right, and obsessionally neurotic. Pretty dangerous, in fact.  34 35 36 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 44.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Do you mean you doubt your power to convince him?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Worse than that: what I'm afraid of is his power to convince me. On the subject of monogamy, for example. Why should we put so much frantic effort into suppressing our most basic natural instincts? SABINA looks at him for a moment with calculating candour

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I don't know; you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a secluded corner of the grounds, OTTO GROSS stands, buckling his belt, above a young NURSE who's more or less naked.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Thank you, I really needed that. And so saying, he uses a convenient tree to scramble up t the top of the brick wall surrounding the gardens. The NU appalled, is still grappling with her clothes, as, with a jaunty, mocking wave, GROSS disappears over the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room in the hospital is in extraordinary disarray, it most conspicuous feature a series, pinned to the wall, of sombre, spidery, somewhat Egon Schiele-like pen-and-ink sketches, mostly nudes. Among them is a sheet of paper labelled DR. JUNG, which JUNG now unpins and turns over. The note says: "Be so good as to tell my father I'm dead. Thanks for you help; and, whatever you do, do not pass by the oasis. Ott JUNG looks up, pensive.  37 38 39 BLUE Revision - 6/5/10 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG stands looking at Sabina's bay window, now lit from within. After a beat, he strides purposefully across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG walks up to the front door and, without hesitation, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA sits at her desk, making notes from some weighty library book, isolated in a pool of light from the oillam There's a light tap at the door. She looks up in surprise then, with a wild hope dawning, gets up, crosses to the d and puts her hand to it.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A friend. She opens the door. Immediately, JUNG takes her in his ar and kisses her. Eventually she breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Come inside. She leads him into the room, closes the door and turns th key in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: She crosses directly to her desk and blows out the lamp. The room is bright with moonlight. She turns to look back JUNG.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Later. CLOSE on SABINA. She cries out as JUNG moves above her on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 39 40 PINK Revision - 6/6/10 46.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Later. They're on the floor, propped up against the desk, SABINA leaning back in JUNG's arms, wrapped in a blanket. There's blood on the sheets. Above SABINA's head, JUNG's expression is haunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA and JUNG stand in front of their new country villa, plain and elegant.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It's so beautiful. I feel as though we've always lived here.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: They say we'll be able to move in by the end of the week. Now JUNG and EMMA, her pregnancy now considerably advance move down the front path towards the lake; EMMA is uncomfortably aware of the ungainliness of her movements.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to be like this again.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: So big and... unattractive.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I expect you wish you were a polygamist, like Otto Gross. They've stopped a few steps away from the front door; JUN is frowning thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: If I were, it would be something quite different from what we have, which is sacred. I would have to be sure you understood that.  PINK Revision - 6/6/10 46A.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't want to know anything about it. JUNG turns towards the door, troubled; EMMA takes his han

dialogues.speaker: EMMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a surprise for you.  4l 42 PINK Revision - 6/6/10 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA leads JUNG beside the house and into the back garden there, tied up at the private jetty, is a sailboat with d red sails.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: The boat you always wanted. With red sails. JUNG is genuinely delighted: he takes EMMA in his arms an kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you for all of this.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You're a good man. You deserve everything that's good. INT. SABINA'S APARTMENT -‚Äî DAY 42 SABINA opens the door to JUNG and throws herself into his arms. It's early evening. JUNG holds her for a moment bef he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: If I say something, will you promise not to take it the wrong way?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Don't you think we ought to stop? Now? SABINA looks up at him, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm married: obviously I'm being deceitful. Is it right for us to perpetuate this deceit?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Do you want to stop?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Of course I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 PINK Revision - 6/6/10 47A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leans down and kisses her passionately; then SABINA dr back and speaks to him very quietly, as she begins to und 42  42 43 44 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 48.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: When you make love to your wife, how is it? Describe it to me.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: When you live under the same roof with someone, it becomes habit, you know: it's always... very tender.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Then this is another thing. Another thing in another country. With me I want you to be ferocious. She takes hold of his large hand.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to punish me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's moments after the birth of JUNG's son, FRANZ, and a NURSE is handing her baby to EMMA, who looks exhausted bu happy. JUNG beams down at her.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I knew it was a boy this time; I told you.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I believed you. She reaches for JUNG with her free hand.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Will you come back to us now? JUNG stoops to move aside a lock of hair stuck to EMMA's damp brow and kisses her reverently on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA stands in the pearly dawn light, looking out acros the lake. This time the Wagner is swooning and lyrical: Lohengrin perhaps. Looming through the mist, the boat with red sails glides towards her.  45 46 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat is at anchor in the centre of the lake. By now, mist has been burned off by the sun. JUNG and SABINA lie enlaced in the bottom of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following year. FADE UP on the terrace above the Belv gardens, in the shadow of the towering baroque palace, lo down across the city of Vienna. The small, dapper figure FREUD, with his gloves and walking-stick, moves alongside the much taller JUNG, formal in dark suit and hat.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I should never have sent Gross to you. I blame myself.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No, I'm very grateful you did. All those provocative discussions helped crystallise a lot of my thinking.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: And did he really send you his hotel bill?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Only for a couple of nights.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: He's an addict: I realise that now. He can only end by doing great harm to our movement. FREUD broods for a moment; then cheers up.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You realise this makes you undisputed Crown Prince, don't you? My son and heir.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I deserve...  46 47 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 50.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Don't say another word. They come to a halt beneath one of the strange, opulently feminine sphinxes which line the fagade of the palace. They look out over the city below.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I often take my walk up here. He looks up at the sphinx for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's inspired some of my best ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The middle of the night. The full ashtray suggests that F and JUNG have been deep in discussion for several hours.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: You mustn't think I have a closed mind. I have absolutely no objection to you studying telepathy or parapsychology to your hearts' content. But I would make the point that our own field is so embattled, it can only be dangerous to stray into any kind of mysticism. Don't you see? We have to stay within the most rigorously scientific confines... He breaks off, frowning at JUNG, who is resting a hand on his stomach, his expression increasingly pained.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes: but I can't agree with you. Why should we draw some arbitrary line and close off whole areas of investigation?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Precisely because the world is full of enemies, looking for any way they (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 51.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: can to discredit us. And the minute they see us abandon the firm ground of sexual theory to wallow in the black mud of superstition, they'll pounce. As far as I'm concerned, even to raise these subjects is professional suicide. Really, you... Again he breaks off, this time because the wood in his bookshelves has cracked, so loudly that it causes FREUD t duck involuntarily.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What in God's name was that?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I knew that was going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I felt something like that was going to happen. I had a kind of burning in my stomach.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? It's the heating, the wood in the bookcase just cracked, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No, it's what's known as a catalytic exteriorisation phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: A catalytic exteriorisation phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: My diaphragm started to glow red hot...  47 48 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 52.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I know it's late, but...

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: And another thing: it's going to happen again,

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: In a minute, it's going to happen again.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: My dear young friend, this is exactly the kind of thing I'm talking about: you must promise me to... But he's interrupted by another deafening report from the bookcase. He looks up at it, for once entirely at a loss words.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You see.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: That's just... you really can't...

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: There are so many mysteries, so much further to go.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Please. We can't be too careful. We can't afford to wander into these speculative areas, telepathy, singing bookcases, fairies at the bottom of the garden. It won't do. JUNG is looking back at him, unconvinced, his jaw stubbor set. INT. SABINA'S APARTMENT -‚Äî DAY 48 JUNG has been making love to SABINA from behind; he's tuc in between her and the wall on her narrow single bed.  48 49 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 53.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: There's a poem by Lermontov keeps going round my head, about a prisoner who finally achieves some happiness when he succeeds in releasing a bird from its cage.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why do you think this is preoccupying you?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I think it means that when I become a doctor, what I want more than anything is to give people back their freedom, the way you gave me mine.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Later. SABINA bends over the corner of the bed; JUNG beat her until she reaches a climax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anxious-looking PATIENT, a woman in her thirties in a dressing-gown, is being helped out of the room by a NURSE and an ORDERLY. FREUD, sitting as an observer in a discre corner of the room, rises to his feet and approaches JUNG speaking with no concern as to whether or not the PATIENT can hear him.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Fascinating. All the standard symptoms of the nymphomaniac. JUNG waits until the door has closed behind the PATIENT.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes; except that whenever anyone responded to her advances, she would run a mile. That's the puzzling feature of the case.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Hm. He looks around the room.  49 50 51 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 54.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I must say it's a great pleasure to see you in your natural habitat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG, with some difficulty, assists a dubious, not to say slightly terrified FREUD aboard the boat with red sails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat glides across the water, taking advantage of a s breeze. FREUD sits bolt upright, as close to the dead cen of the boat as he can manage, facing JUNG, who lolls back shirtsleeves, a hand on the tiller.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: There's a rumour running around Vienna that you've taken one of your patients as a mistress. JUNG sits up: he's very shocked; it takes him a moment to recover.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It's absolutely untrue.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Well, of course it is. So I've been telling everyone.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What's being said?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, that the woman's been bragging about it, that somebody's sending out anonymous letters, usual sort of thing. Bound to happen, sooner or later, it's an occupational hazard. He shakes his head, amused.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These women: the way they try to seduce us, the way they use every conceivable psychic wile. It's one of nature's most dramatic spectacles.  51 52 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 55.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes: I hope I'd never be stupid enough to get emotionally involved with a patient. He adjusts the tiller, his composure beginning to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are closed. SABINA lies in bed, watching unhappily as JUNG finishes dressing. Eventually, he sits a chair facing her, knotting his tie, his expression grav

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm confused. I feel trapped, I've trapped myself into feeling divided and... guilty.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I've never wanted you to feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I don't see how we can go on. He rises unsteadily to his feet. SABINA springs out of be and flings her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: You mustn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I have some kind of illness. Try to remember the love and patience I showed towards you when you were ill. That's what I need from you now.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Of course. You have it. Always. But please don't go. He looks down at her trembling body.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I must. I have to. He detaches himself from her, turns and hurries out of th apartment, grabbing his coat and hat from behind the door  53 54 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and EMMA are eating dinner: he seems distracted.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I can't say I was sorry to say goodbye to him. Not the easiest houseguest we've ever had.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No. I don't think he ever recovered from his first view of the house. JUNG shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suppose, compared to that tiny flat in Vienna...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Why did he refuse to meet the Herr Direktor?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Oh, he's always been a great one for bearing incomprehensible grudges. EMMA looks at him, her expression changing.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Did he say anything to you about anonymous letters? JUNG looks up, shocked. He stops eating in mid-chew. EMMA watches him for a second, then speaks, very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Surely you didn't think I'd let you go without putting up a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG sits, very tense, behind his desk, waiting. He's sta to get up when there's a knock at the door. He sits down again.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Come in.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 57.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SABINA surges into the room, slamming the door behind her

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: How could you treat me this way?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Sit down! Tense silence: then she sits in the chair furthest away f his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tried to explain the situation to your mother.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I don't know how you dared say those things to her.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: She came in waving an anonymous letter, demanding to know if it was true. I told her even if it were, the position would not be quite as she imagined, since you're no longer my patient.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Of course I'm your patient!

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Technically not, not since I stopped charging you.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: That's what she said; I told her I didn't believe her and she told me you said your fee was ten francs a consultation.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 58.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I was trying to point out that I would take you back as a patient, but that I could only undertake to see you inside this office.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: How can you be so cold and offhand?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I was trying to make her understand the distinction between a patient and a friend. He makes a huge effort to remain calm.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, I've made a stupid mistake...

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Is that what it was?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I broke one of the elementary rules of my profession. I'm your doctor: and I believe I did you some good. I can't forgive myself for overstepping the mark: I should have known that if I gave you what you wanted, you wouldn't be able to help wanting more.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I don't want more, I never wanted more, I never asked for more.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You didn't have to ask.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Even if you're right, which I dispute, you think this is a proper way to behave towards me? Refusing to speak to me except in your office?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm your physician: from now on, that's all I can be.  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 59.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. Finally, SABINA looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Don't you love me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Only as your physician.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: You think I'm going to stand for this?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What choice do you have? Moving with tremendous speed, SABINA is on her feet and r the desk, where she deals him a staggering openhanded blo to the face. JUNG struggles to his feet under a rain of b until he's able to grip her wrists.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to understand: I'm your physician! She's glaring fiercely at him; as soon as he releases her wrists, once again moving like lightning, she grabs the p knife from the desk and lunges at him.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Then heal thyself! She's opened up a gash on his cheek: and as he puts up an astonished hand to feel the blood which is starting to we she goes for him again. This time, he's able to grasp her wrist and disarm her after a short, vicious, struggle. Sh takes a couple of steps back, still shaking with fury. Th she reaches into her bag, pulls out a tenfranc note and s it on to his cheek, where it adheres.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And there's your ten francs! She rushes blindly from the room, leaving JUNG standing amazed, reaching up to peel the banknote from his bloody cheek.  55 56 57 58 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA is at her desk in a pool of lamplight, dressed in nightgown, pen in hand. She begins to write.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Professor Freud... She looks up, clearing away tears with the back of her ha

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-+.-I would be most grateful if you would allow me to come and visit you in Vienna on a matter of great interest to us both...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD is at his desk, writing.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear friend, I have just received this extremely strange letter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG sits in his beautifully designed new study with its views of the garden leading down to the lake, reading a l from FREUD, while in the other hand he holds SABINA's let

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you know this woman? Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG and EMMA take tea at a table close to the lake. The baby, FRANZ, is in his pram, while the two girls, AGATHE, and GRET, 3, play under the watchful eye of their NURSEMA EMMA is watching JUNG, who looks pale and tense and a tho miles away.
