dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As you will no doubt recall, Spielrein was the case that brought you and me together, for which reason I have always regarded her with special gratitude and affection: until I (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 60 61 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 61.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: understood that she was systematically planning my seduction. Now I have no idea what her intentions may be: revenge, I suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD reads JUNG's letter.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have never shown such friendship to a patient, nor have I ever been made to suffer so much in return. I am hoping you will agree to act as a kind of go-between and avert a disaster. FREUD frowns, scratching his chin and puffing at his ciga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG sits alone at the tiller of his boat. The weather is overcast, the lake choppy and deserted.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your famous saying is carved in block letters on my heart: "Whatever you do, give up any idea of trying to cure them." He takes a letter out of his pocket to re-read it.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Experiences like this, however painful, are necessary and inevitable. Without them, how can we know life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD is poised to write. Beside him, the methodical pile his daily correspondence.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Miss Spielrein, Dr. Jung is a good friend and colleague of mine, whom I believe to be incapable of frivolous or shabby behaviour. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 62 63 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 62.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What I infer from your letter is that you used to be close friends, but are no longer so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA lies on her narrow bed, sobbing, the pages of FREU letter spread out across her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If this is the case, I would urge you to consider whether the feelings that have survived this close friendship are not best suppressed and forgotten; and without the intervention and involvement of third persons, such as myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG is in the process of clearing out his office, loadin books and papers into cardboard boxes. The scar on his ch has almost disappeared. He looks up and is shocked to see SABINA standing in the doorway. When he speaks, his tone harsh.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I heard you were leaving the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: As you see.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: People are saying it's because of the scandal I caused.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'd been planning to leave anyway.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry if I... precipitated it.  63 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 63.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You've always been something of a catalyst. SABINA advances a little further into the room, her tone less defensive.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I've had a letter from Professor Freud.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: The thing that shone through was how much he loves you. JUNG nods abruptly, his reaction to this evidently ambiva

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But what was also clear is that you denied everything. You let him think I was a fantasist or a liar.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I don't see that it's any of his business.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I've come to ask you to tell him the truth.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I want you to write and tell him everything. JUNG is obviously horrified by this suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I want him to write to me again to confirm you've told him everything.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Are you blackmailing me?  63 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 64.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'm asking you to tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why is this so important to you?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I want him to take me as his patient. JUNG is appalled.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Does it have to be him?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: It has to be him. She looks at him for a moment, considering his tormented expression.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't feel the same way about him, do you?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm disappointed by his rigid pragmatism, his insistence that nothing can possibly exist, unless some puny and transitory intelligence has first become aware of it.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: All the same, will you write to him? JUNG looks away, not answering.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I could have damaged you, you know, far worse than I did. I chose not to.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: All right, I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Thank you. It means everything to me.  63 64 65 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 65.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JUNG moves to look out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Are you going somewhere for the summer?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Berlin, with my parents.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: But you are going to come back to the University? To qualify?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I'm going to America. With Freud, although he doesn't yet know it.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: That's nice. Goodbye. JUNG turns back from the window, surprised: but she's alr gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD has a letter in his hand: he's looking into the mid distance with an expression of considerable satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-in view of my friendship for the patient and her complete trust in me, what I did was indefensible; I confess this, very unhappily, to you, my father-figure... FREUD permits himself a very faint smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA stands surrounded by suitcases in front of her apartment building. A taxi pulls up at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Miss Spielrein, I owe you an apology. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 67 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 66.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But the fact that I was wrong and that the man is to be blamed rather than the woman, satisfies my own need to revere women. Please accept my admiration for the very dignified way you have resolved this conflict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As, from her P.O.V., the apartment building recedes and vanishes, SABINA turns back, a prey to conflicting emotio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small knot of psychoanalysts has gathered at the foot o the gangplank leading up to the imposing height of the S. George Washington to see off JUNG, FREUD and their travel companion, SANDOR FERENCZI, 36, a mild-looking Hungarian analyst and fervent disciple of FREUD. Setting off up the gangplank FREUD pauses to wave regally to his followers; then he turns somewhat irritably to FERENCZI.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Do we have all the necessary paperwork, Ferenczi?

dialogues.speaker: FERENCZI
dialogues.text: I have everything. Professor.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I've always been in two minds about America. Are we making a foolish error? Do they really want us there?

dialogues.speaker: FERENCZI
dialogues.text: They postponed the Congress two months so that you could attend, Professor. Surely that gives you some indication.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Yes. By contrast to FREUD, JUNG looks genuinely exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I think it's going to be a great adventure.  67

dialogues.speaker: 67A
dialogues.text: 68 BLUE Revision - 6/5/10 67.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I hope you're right. But he continues to look sceptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they've reached the head of the gangplank and an OFFICER is inspecting the papers proffered by JUNG and FERENCZI. JUNG's papers are returned first, with a deferential bow.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I go this way.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I left my wife to make the arrangements: I'm afraid she's booked me a first-class stateroom.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I see. He's extremely displeased. He glares after JUNG as the la sets off, escorted by a STEWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship glides slowly through Atlantic fog across a glas sea. FREUD, wrapped in heavy overcoat and plaid blanket, shuffles around the deck, accompanied by JUNG, who has to keep slowing down so as not to leave him behind.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I was on the Swiss-Austrian border, somewhere in the mountains, at dusk. There was a long wait, because everybody's baggage was being searched. I noticed a decrepit customs official wearing the old royal and imperial uniform and I was watching him walking up and down, with his melancholy and disgruntled expression, when someone said to me: "He isn't really there, he's a ghost, who still hasn't found out how to die properly."  68 BLUE Revision - 6/5/10

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Is that the whole dream? 67A. 68  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 68.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: All I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Did you say the Swiss-Austrian border?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Must have something to do with us.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Everybody's being searched. Perhaps that's an indication that the ideas which used to flow so freely between us are now subject to the most suspicious examination.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You mean the ideas flowing in your direction.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: And I'm afraid the old relic shuffling about in this entirely useless fashion must almost certainly be me.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Whom you very mercifully wish could be put out of his misery. A humane death wish.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Perhaps the fact he was unable to die simply indicated the immortality of his ideas.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: So you agree it must have been me?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 69.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Never mind, it's a most entertaining example. He stops for a moment, to look out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What about you, do you have a dream to report?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I had a most elaborate dream last night. Particularly rich.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Let's hear it. Silence. JUNG is left staring at FREUD's back for some ti

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I'd love to tell you, but I don't think I should.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why ever not? FREUD turns to look at him, smiles mirthlessly.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to risk my authority. JUNG's mouth opens and shuts; he's nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The George Washington steams past the Statue of Liberty towards the dazzling New York skyline. FREUD contemplates it, frowning; he's flanked by JUNG. JUNG is absolutely entranced.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Take it from me, what you're looking at is the future.  69 70 71 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 70.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: But do you think they have any idea we're on our way, bringing them the plague? JUNG looks at FREUD with incomprehension. They are standi shoulder to shoulder, but there seems a thousand miles be them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA is 25 now, her hair fashionably restyled and her d new. She walks firmly down the long, tree-lined stone pathway leading to the intimidating tower of the Jungs' villa, bu hesitates at the front door, a little overcome: then she summons up her courage and tugs at the bell-pull. A CAPTION: KUSNACHT, 25TH SEPTEMBER, 1910.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA stands in the window, looking out at the garden an the lake beyond; she's considerably startled by the VOICE AGATHE JUNG, now 6, who has come into the room without he noticing.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHE
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Sabina.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHE
dialogues.text: Sabina. Hello, Sabina. My name's Agathe.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Hello, Agathe.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHE
dialogues.text: Are you staying to lunch?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I don't think she can today. So say goodbye.  71 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Again, SABINA is startled, this time by JUNG, who's spoke on his way into the room.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHE
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Sabina.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Agathe. The little girl runs out of the room, leaving the two adu looking intensely constrained. SABINA is making a not ent successful effort not to tremble. He motions for her to sit down and reaches for a bulky document on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Whose idea was it that you should send me your dissertation?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: The Herr Direktor.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: He kept insisting this was the kind of material you were looking for for your Yearbook.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It certainly is a very fascinating case you've chosen to investigate. But if we're to consider it for the Yearbook there are one or two mistakes which will have to be dealt with.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Might you have a little time to discuss all this?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Well, yes.  71 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 72.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: When I left the hospital and moved out here, I was afraid it would take years to build up a roster of patients, but I'm afraid we're already under siege. He reaches for his diary, starts to consult it.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: How's... Mrs. Jung?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Very well: I don't suppose you'll be amazed to hear she's expecting another addition to the family any day now.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Your house is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Thanks. Anyway, I don't see why a little more work shouldn't make your dissertation eminently publishable.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Do you think we'd be able to work on it together without...? She breaks off. They look at one another for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It's always going to be something of a risk, seeing one another.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: But I believe we have the character to be able to deal with the situation, don't you?  71

dialogues.speaker: 71A
dialogues.text: 72 BLUE Revision - 6/5/10 73.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I hope so. Dangerous silence.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I somehow imagined you'd have found another admirer by now. JUNG looks away; then back to her.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No. You were the jewel of great price. He makes an effort and resumes a businesslike tone.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we say this time next Tuesday? And I'll start gently ripping you to shreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG contemplates Sabina's apartment. He lights his pipe, then crosses the street. INT. SABINA'S APARTMENT -‚Äî DAY 72 Back in Sabina's old apartment, now somewhat spruced up, JUNG and SABINA discuss the dissertation which lies sprea out on the coffee table in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Explain this analogy you make between the sex instinct and the death instinct.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Professor Freud claims the sexual drive arises from a simple urge towards pleasure. If he's right, the question is why is this urge so often successfully repressed?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You used to have a theory involving the impulse towards destruction and self-destruction: losing oneself.  BLUE Revision - 6/5/10 73A.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Well, suppose we think of sexuality as fusion, losing oneself, as you say, but losing oneself in the other, (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 74 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 74.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: in other words, destroying one's own individuality. Wouldn't the ego, in self-defence, automatically resist that impulse?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: You mean for selfish not for social reasons?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm saying perhaps true sexuality demands the destruction of the ego.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: (with quiet satisfaction) In other words, the opposite of what Freud proposes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA cries out in pain. She's bent along the top of the sofa. Her hands are tied together with a leather belt and she's watching herself in the mirror on the opposite wall JUNG moves behind her, causing her to cry out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG, sitting at a small table, clothes in disarray, scri a note on Sabina's dissertation. SABINA, on the other sid of the room, looks at him, her face tense as she winds up the courage to say what she feels she has to.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: When I graduate, I've decided to leave Ziirich. JUNG looks up, completely taken by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: You know why.  74 75 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 75.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence, broken by a deep sigh from JUNG.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: It's true: I'm nothing but a philistine Swiss bourgeois. A complacent coward. I want to break away and leave everything and disappear with you and then... comes the voice of the philistine. (pause) Where will you go?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Vienna, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Please don't go there.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I must go wherever I need to feel free. Abruptly, JUNG bursts into tears; he gets up from his des moves round it and crashes to his knees in front of SABIN burying his face in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Don't. She looks down at his large head and heaving shoulders wi infinite sadness, but, as she reaches down to stroke his hair, she's dry-eyed and determined-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP on FREUD, as he lights his cigar and contemplates SABINA benevolently across his desk. A CAPTION: TWO YEARS LATER. VIENNA, 17TH APRIL, 1912.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: You know, your paper led to one of the most stimulating discussions we've ever had at the Psychoanalytic Society. Do you really think the sexual drive...  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 76.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He breaks off briefly to consult his notes.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..is a ‚Äòdemonic and destructive force'?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes, at the same time as being a creative force, in the sense that it can produce, out of the destruction of two individualities, a new being. But the individual always has to overcome a resistance because of the self-annihilating nature of the sexual act.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I've fought against the idea for some time, but I suppose there must be some kind of indissoluble link between sex and death. I don't feel the relationship between the two is quite as you've portrayed it, but I'm most grateful to you for animating the subject in such a stimulating way. The only slight shock was your introduction, at the very end of your paper, of the name of Christ.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Are you completely opposed to any kind of religious dimension in our field?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: In general, I don't care if a man believes in Rama, Marx or Aphrodite, as long as he keeps it out of the consulting room.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Is that what's at the bottom of your dispute with Dr. Jung?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I have no dispute with Dr. Jung. I was simply mistaken about him. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 77.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought he was going to be able to carry our work forward, after I was gone; I didn't bargain for all that second-rate mysticism and self- aggrandising shamanism. I didn't realise he could be so brutal and sanctimonious.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: He's trying to find some way forward, so that we don't just have to tell our patients, this is why you are the way you are; he wants to be able to say, we can show you what you might want to become.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Playing God, in other words. We have no right to do that. The world is as it is: understanding and accepting that is the way to psychic health. What good can we do if our aim is simply to replace one delusion with another?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Well, I agree with you.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I've noticed that in the crucial areas of dispute between Dr. Jung and myself, you tend to favour me.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I thought you had no dispute with him. FREUD smiles, acknowledging he's been caught out. Then, h brow furrows.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: You still love him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: That's not why I'm pleading his cause. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 78.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just feel that if you two don't find a way to co-exist, it will hold back the progress of psychoanalysis, perhaps indefinitely.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: If you still love him, it's because you haven't yet understood the hatred he deserves. I believe he's quite capable of destroying all the good work of the last twenty years and putting nothing of value in its place. However, since you do love him, I'll restrain myself.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Is there no way to avert a rupture?

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Correct scientific relations will be maintained, of course. I'1l be seeing him at the editorial meeting in Munich in November and I shall be perfectly civil. To tell you the truth, what finished him for me was all that business about you, the lies, the ruthless behaviour. I was very shocked. On your behalf.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I think he loved me.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: All the more reason to behave better, wouldn't you say? I'm afraid your idea of a mystical union with a blond Siegfried was inevitably doomed. Put not your trust in Aryans. We're Jews, my dear Miss Spielrein; and Jews we will always be. SABINA looks back at him, surprised by the sudden intensi in his voice. Aware of this, he takes a puff of his cigar and speaks in a quite different tone.  75 76 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 79.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now: the real reason I invited you here this evening was to ask if you'd be prepared to take on one or two of my patients. SABINA's face lights up in genuine delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present are the presidents of the local societies: Freud, Jung, Abraham, Seif, Ernest Jones, Riklin, and Johan van Ophuijsen, secretary of the Ziirich society. JUNG is on his feet, gathering up his papers, as the rest the DELEGATES, who have been sitting round a long table covered in green baize, now littered with half-empty cara and glasses of water, head for the doors. FREUD, at the head of the table, some way away, is also marshalling his documents. They're obviously going to be the last two men left in the room; and, as if bowing to t inevitable, reluctantly, FREUD eventually speaks.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: I think that was a fairly satisfactory session, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I was interested in what you said about monotheism: that it arose historically out of some kind of patricidal impulse.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Yes, Akhnaton, who as far as we know was the first to put forward the bizarre notion that there was only one God, also had his father's name erased and chiselled out of all public monuments.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: That's not strictly true. FREUD pauses in the act of tidying his papers. He looks u at JUNG, a ferocious glint in his eye.  76 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 80.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Not true?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: You mean it's most probably a myth?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No. I mean there were two perfectly straightforward reasons for Akhnaton, or Amenhopis IV, as I prefer to call him, to excise his father's name from the cartouches. First, this was something traditionally done by all new kings, who didn't wish their father's names to continue to be public currency.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: In much the same way as your article in the Yearbook fails to mention my name? The atmosphere is becoming electric.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Your name is so well-known, it hardly seemed necessary to mention it.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Do go on.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Secondly, Amenhopis only struck out the first half of his father's name, Amenhotep, because, like the first half of his own name, it was shared by Amon, one of the gods he was determined to eliminate.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: As simple as that?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: The explanation doesn't seem to me unduly simple.  76 77 78 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 81.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: And you think your man, whatever you call him, felt no hostility whatsoever towards his father?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I've no means of proof, of course. For all I know, Amenhopis may have thought his father's name was quite familiar enough and that now it might be time to make a name for himself. At which point, FREUD faints, pitching forward, ricocheti off the table and ending in a heap on the floor. JUNG bou forward, gathers him up in his arms, carries him across t room and lowers him gently on to one of the old brown sof which line the walls. FREUD comes to; and looks up at JUN fear and vulnerability openly expressed on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: How sweet it must be to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG sits at his desk, writing a letter.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If I may say so, dear Professor, you make the mistake of treating your friends like patients. This enables you to reduce them to the level of children, so that their only choice is to become obsequious nonentities or bullying enforcers of the party line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD sits, frowning, in a haze of cigar smoke, reading a letter.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .+-while you sit on the mountaintop, the infallible father-figure; and nobody dares to pluck you by the beard and say: think about your behaviour and then decide which one of us is the neurotic. I speak as a friend.  78 79 80 81 82 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 82.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FREUD utters a bark of incredulous laughter and reaches f his pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG looks up from his substantial breakfast as the MAID arrives with his correspondence on a silver tray. He reac for the letters, sees immediately the familiar handwritin on one of them and impatiently breaks open the letter.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your letter cannot be answered. Your claim that I treat my friends like patients is self-evidently untrue. As to which of us is the neurotic, I thought we analysts were agreed a little neurosis was nothing whatever to be ashamed of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD walks past the statues of the sphinxes, deep in tho It's a foggy morning, the city below shrouded in mist.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But a man like you, who behaves quite abnormally and then stands there shouting at the top of his voice how normal he is, does give considerable cause for concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG reads on, his face flushing with anger.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For a long time now, our relationship has been hanging by a thread; and a thread, moreover, mostly consisting of past disappointments. We have nothing to lose by cutting it. JUNG crumples the letter; he looks at the same time furio and bereft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREUD paces up and down, plainly very agitated.  82 83 84 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 83.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You will be the best judge of what this moment means to you. The rest is silence. Finally, FREUD moves to the bookshelf, where he picks up framed photograph of JUNG, considers it with a pained expression, and then lays it back, face down, on the shel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNG sits alone, out on the lake, in the boat with red sa His face sinks into his hands and he gives an anguished g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful sunny day, the following summer, 1913. JUNG sits in a large wicker chair, looking out across the lake. He looks pale and unwell; and despite the sunlight, there's a blanket over his knees. Not far off, tea is being cleared away; and the four JUNG children play under the supervision of their NURSEMAID. Still at the table are EMMA JUNG and SABINA, who wears a wedding ring and is quite unmistakably pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: So good to have met you at last, Dr. Spielrein.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: We did meet once before. When I was your husband's patient.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I think you're right.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Your children are glorious.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Thank you. You must let us know when yours arrives. I expect you want a boy.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: No, no: my husband and I both think we would prefer a girl.  84 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 84.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Really. The children are being taken away: but AGATHE, 8 now, bre away from them.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHE
dialogues.text: Can't I stay?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No, run along with the others.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHE
dialogues.text: Oh, look... She's seen a butterfly and runs off in pursuit of it. EMM turns back to SABINA.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I wish you could help him.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Why, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: He's not himself. He's very confused and bogged down with his book. He's not sleeping. He's not taking on any new patients. He still hasn't recovered from the violence of his break with Professor Freud. I've been around this kind of thing enough to feel almost sure he's heading for a nervous breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: What you're describing is very unlike my memory of him.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: If you were staying in town, I'd try to persuade him to let you analyse him. I know he... always set great store by your opinion. You are taking patients now?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 85.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I've pretty much decided to specialise in child psychology. I'm not sure it's a field he approves of, I haven't discussed it with him. But I think if the problem can be caught early enough...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: When the children are of age, I'm intending to become a therapist. Although I haven't discussed it with Carl either.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: You must be under a great strain. JUNG raises his head and looks across at them.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You'd better go and talk to him. She's about to move off: SABINA stops her.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: No one can help him more than you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I hope you're right. SABINA leans forward and kisses her on both cheeks; then moves over to join JUNG.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: You have beautiful children. JUNG looks up at her: he ignores her remark completely.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: So, you're married.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: And he's a doctor?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 86.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes. His name is Pavel Scheftel.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Russian?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes, a Russian Jew.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Kind.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Good, good. He looks away, a spasm of pain crossing his face.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes. I haven't been sleeping very well. I keep having this apocalyptic dream. A terrible flood from the North Sea to the Alps: houses washed away, thousands of floating corpses. Eventually it comes crashing down into the lake in a great tidal wave; and by this time, the water, roaring down like some vast avalanche, has turned into blood. The blood of Europe.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: What do you think it means?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I've no idea: unless it's about to happen. He turns back to SABINA.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are your plans?  WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 87.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: We've been thinking of going back to Russia.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: As long as you leave Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I spoke to him last week. I can't believe there's nothing to be done to...

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be done! The day he refused to discuss a dream with me on the grounds that it might risk his authority I should have known. After that, for me, he had no authority. It was a blow when I discovered you'd chosen his side.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: It's not a question of sides. I have to work in the direction my instinct tells my intelligence is the right one. Don't forget, you cured me with his method. And your differences are not as great as you both think. If you could only find a way to advance together.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Is that what you came here to say?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: No. I was passing through from Geneva. Naturally, I thought I would stop and visit. I have to go for my train very soon.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, I'm sorry, I'm not... He breaks off, looks out across the lake again.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It can't be done. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What he'll never accept is that what we understand has got us nowhere. We have to go into uncharted territory. We have to go back, to the sources of everything we believe. I don't just want to open a door and show the patient his illness, squatting there like a toad. I want to find a way to help the patient reinvent himself, to send him off on a journey, at the end of which is waiting the person he was always intended to be.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: But it's no good making yourself ill in the process.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Only the wounded physician can hope to heal. Silence. SABINA breaks it, her tone calm.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: I'm told you have a new mistress.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Toni.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Is she like me?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: She's an ex-patient.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes. 88. 84  84 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 89.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Half Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Training to be an analyst.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: But she's not like me?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: Naturally, she makes me think of you.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: How do you make it work?

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: I don't know. Emma, as you've seen, is the foundation of my house; Toni is the perfume in the air. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My love for you was the most important thing in my life. For better or worse, it made me understand who I am. SABINA's eyes fill with tears. JUNG reaches out and rests hand on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This should be mine.

dialogues.speaker: SABINA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNG
dialogues.text: But sometimes you have to do something unforgivable, just to be able to go on living.  84 85 86 87 WHITE Revision - 4-22-10 90.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leans forward and kisses her gently on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At sunset, a taxi putters along the lakeside road leading away from Kiisnacht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABINA turns back from the window. Her expression, though full of emotion, is calm and not unhappy. She rests a hand lightly on her belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun shimmers red-gold on the ethereally tranquil lake JUNG sits, looking out across the water, lost in painful reflection. And the SOUND gradually swells, growing loud louder, of some vast avalanche, crashing down the mountai As this SOUND and IMAGE gradually FADE, A FINAL roller BE OTTO GROSS starved to death in Berlin in 1919. SIGMUND FREUD was driven out of Vienna by the Nazis and d of cancer in London in 1939. SABINA SPIELREIN returned to Russia, trained a number of most distinguished analysts of the new Soviet Union and finally returned to practise medicine in her native town, Rostov-on-Don. In 1941, by now a widow, she and her two daughters were taken by Nazi occupying forces to a local synagogue and shot. CARL GUSTAV JUNG suffered a prolonged nervous breakdown d the First World War, from which he emerged to become, eventually, the world's leading psychologist. He outlived his wife, EMMA, and his mistress, TONI WOLFF, and died peacefully in 1961. 84 85 86 87
